Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Heat Flow and Hydrothermal Transport in the Panama Basin Linked with Geophysical and Oceanographic Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigation of hydrothermal heat and mass flux between the crust and the ocean between the Costa Rica Rift axis and Ocean Drilling Program Hole 504B is designed to aid in development of an integrated crust-hydrothermal-ocean circulation model. Heat flow will be measured along a 300 km long corridor as an integral component of a large multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional project called OSCAR (Oceanographic and Seismic Characterization of heat dissipation and alteration by hydrothermal fluids at an Axial Ridge). In combination with oceanographic plume mapping that will guide assessment of hydrothermal flux at the spreading axis, the new heat flow results will show how conductive flux varies as the plate ages, in particular where the transition from focused, high rate flow to diffuse, lower flux circulation occurs. This is a long-standing question in mid-ocean ridge studies. The influence of disrupted basement structure on local heatflow will be assessed.

US scientists will work closely with UK and German colleagues that lead the main project. Addition of the heat flow acquisition enables addressing a main theme of the InterRidge Third Decade plan- heat and chemical exchange between the crust and the deep ocean. A female graduate student whose main training is in analytical modeling will gain experience in seagoing data acquisition, exposure to international scientists, and insight into the advantages and limitations of having surface-only data to constrain a subsurface flow model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal objective of this collaborative research project was to collect and analyze conductive heat flow data in young sediment-covered oceanic crust in the Panama Basin between the Costa Rica Rift axis and DSDP/ODP Hole 504B to aid in the development of an integrated crustal evolution-hydrothermal-ocean circulation model. This research complemented and formed an integral component of the large multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional project lead by Dr. Richard Hobbs at the University of Durham, England called OSCAR (Oceanographic and Seismic Characterization of heat dissipation and alteration by hydrothermal fluids at an Axial Ridge). The heat flow data, when coupled with the geophysical and physical oceanographic data collected during seagoing expeditions to the study area, was expected to provide the first detailed understanding of how conductive and advective heat and mass transfer at the seafloor affects deep ocean circulation.  In addition to the principal objective, the research provided a preliminary assessment of hydrothermal heat output on the Costa Rica Rift.

A total of 85 new conductive heat flow measurements were made during expedition JC113 on the British vessel RSS James Cook between December 2014 and January 2015 with a multi-penetration heat flow probe maintained and operated by Dr. Robert Harris of Oregon State University. Eighteen of these measurements were made in a sediment pond within the Ecuador Fracture Zone south of the Ecuador Rift. The remaining 67 measurements were made at five separate sites co-located with a high-resolution seismic reflection line that extended from the ridge axis to Hole 504B.

The eighteen measurements in the Ecuador Fracture Zone showed that the heat flux increased from the younger to the older crust, which was surprising since one would expect fluid flow to proceed from older, colder crust to younger, hotter crust. Moreover, the mean heat flow in the sediment pond was approximately 50% of what was expected based on conductive cooling as the crust aged. These results have been presented at national geophysics meetings and have been published in the peer-reviewed journal, Earth and Planetary Science Letters.  Heat flow measurements in fracture zones are surprisingly rare and this limited data set provides important new insights into the thermal regime of fracture zones.  More heat flow data is needed better assess the role of hydrothermal circulation on the thermal regime of fracture zones and it impact on their tectonic evolution.

A total of 67 heat flow measurements were made at five separate sites, spanning crustal ages between 1.3 and 5.4 Myr.  Sediment cover is relatively incomplete in this region and varies between 0 and 290 m. The majority of heat flow values fall below theoretical crustal cooling models indicating that a significant fraction of the heat is removed by hydrothermal circulation. Low heat flow values are observed in sediment ponds between abyssal hill relief and high values are generally associated with ridge-ward dipping faults bounding abyssal hills. These faults are likely high permeability pathways where heated fluids are exiting the crust. The mean heat flow at the different sites varies between 0.08 of the theoretical value on 1 million year old crust to very near the theoretical values at 5.5 Ma. Individual heat flow values range between 0.01 and 4.1 of the predicted value, suggesting that a significant fraction of the heat is removed advectively, with high values indicating sites of fluid discharge.  This analysis was presented at the Fall 2016 meeting of the American Geophysical Union. Additional work on this data set is ongoing.

Conductivity-temperature-depth profiles along with a measurement of light transmission provided evidence of a hydrothermal plume approximately 800 meters above the Costa Rica Rift axis.  These data were used with buoyant plume theory to estimate heat output from the axis in the range between 350 and 550 megawatts, which is similar to other ridge axis hydrothermal systems. Seismic data show the presence of a magma body approximately 2 kilometers beneath the ridge axis, which likely provides the heat to drive the hydrothermal flow. This analysis was presented at the Fall 2016 meeting of the American Geophysical Union.

In terms of broader impacts, the project serves as part of a female graduate student’s doctoral research and thus contributes to the development and training of a young scientist. In addition the results have advanced the study of marine geophysics as a result of the new heat flow data and analysis, particularly at fracture zones
